You could embed them in resin - UV setting resin doesn't need to be thick, just put a coating on them.  Then, fill in the base with a thin layer of the style that is used to mimic water - it will sink into the dry sand and solidify it for the base...I used it to mimic water for lotus plants I created in cold porcelain...it sunk into the sand at first until saturated.  I let it harden then added more for the water look, so only use enough to seal it all, no extra water effect needed.  Must be dry first though.  Blessings!

The outer shell has more glue in it because the water can evaporate off the surface as well as draining-down. As the water evaporates off the outside, water inside will diffuse through the sand (from the wetter inside to the drier outer surfaces). That water carries the glue with it, concentrating the glue in the outer surfaces. I think it also carries some of the food colouring as well - in the shots where they show a glue-castle breaking apart, it looks like the sand inside has much less colour than the outer glue-shell layer.

The stalagmite comparison is very apt. Because this is almost exactly how stalagmites are formed. Water picks up a slight acidity, dissolves some rock as it is flowing through it, and when it drips from a cavern roof in one spot for long enough, the minerals it is carrying get deposited and a stalagmite forms.
